title-group.article-title: Single nucleotide polymorphism of CD40 region and the risk of systemic lupus erythematosus

abstract.p: There is one study on the association of the CD40 G > T (rs4810485) single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) as a risk factor of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Therefore, we studied the prevalence of the CD40 G > T SNP in patients with SLE (n = 261) and controls (n = 545) in a Polish population. We did not find significant differences between the CD40 G > T genotype and allele frequency in patients with SLE and healthy individuals. However, the frequency of the CD40 TT and GT genotypes was statistically different between patients with arthritis and neurologic manifestations and patients without these symptoms (OR = 0.2009 (95% CI = 0.07547–0.5348, p = 0.0004, pcorr = 0.0068) and OR = 0.2876 (95% CI = 0.1371–0.6031, p = 0.0005, pcorr = 0.0085) respectively). Our observations indicate that the CD40 T variant might be negatively associated with some clinical disease manifestations in patients with SLE.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a multifactorial systemic autoimmune disease characterized by the development of an immune response directed against the body’s own tissues.1 Despite the fact that SLE has been intensively studied, the underlying cause of this autoimmune disease remains elusive.1 The interactions between environmental and genetic factors in the development of SLE have been well documented.2,3 The genetic risk factors mainly include many genes related to the immune system.4–7 Genome wide association studies have demonstrated that numerous genetic loci exhibit low-to-moderate susceptibility for SLE.4,7 The most significant genes increasing the risk of SLE are situated in the HLA locus; however, other genes encoding molecules regulating the function of immune cells also contribute to SLE.4–7 One of these genes, encoding CD40, has been identified as a genetic risk factor for rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and is also recognized as a risk factor for SLE.8,9

CD40 is a member of the tumor necrosis factor (TNF) receptor superfamily that was originally identified as both a B-cell costimulatory receptor and a tumor antigen presented in bladder carcinoma.10 CD40 is presented constitutively on the surface of B cells, dendritic cells, and macrophages, and under certain conditions can also be presented on monocytes, basophils, eosinophils, and T cells.10 Moreover, CD40 is located on the surface of non-immune cells such as endothelial, neuronal, epithelial, and smooth muscle cells and keratinocytes.11–13 CD40 plays an important role in T-cell-dependent B-cell humoral responses, regulation of cytokines, growth factor production in monocytes, and modulation of adhesion molecule density on the endothelial cell surface.13 CD40 may be involved in the pathogenesis and exacerbation of different human autoimmune diseases, including SLE.14 The pathogenic effect of CD40–CD40 ligand (CD40L) interactions has been well determined in both the murine SLE model and human SLE.15,16 Therefore, the single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) modulating CD40 gene expression may increase the risk of autoimmune disease.

There is one study on the association of the CD40 G > T (rs4810485) SNP with an increased risk for SLE.9 Therefore, we aimed to study whether CD40 G > T (rs4810485) can be a genetic risk factor of SLE in the Polish population. Because SLE is a heterogeneous disease, we also assessed the association of this SNP with various clinical symptoms of SLE.

sec.title: Patients and controls
sec.p:
Data for 261 women fulfilling the American College of Rheumatology Classification criteria for SLE17–18 were sequentially collected for the study at the Institute of Rheumatology in Warsaw, Poland (Table 1). Controls included 545 unrelated healthy volunteers and healthy women selected during medical examination at the Institute of Mother and Child, Warsaw. Women with SLE and controls were of Polish Caucasian origin and of a similar age. The mean age of SLE patients at diagnosis was 36 ± 9 years, and of controls 35 ± 8 years. sec.title: Genotyping
sec.p: DNA was isolated from peripheral leukocytes using a standard salting out procedure. Identification of the CD40 (rs4810485) polymorphic variant was performed by polymerase chain reaction-restriction fragment length polymorphism (PCR-RFLP). PCR was conducted employing primer pair 5′ TGTATTTTTGTAGTTCCTCATTCT 3′ and 5′ TTCCCTTGCTTTCCTTGATACC 3′. The PCR-amplified fragments of CD40, which were 157 bp in length, were isolated and digested with the endonuclease MspI (C/CGG) (New England BioLabs, Ipswich, USA). The CD40 G allele was cleaved into 105 bp and 52 bp fragments, whereas the CD40 T allele remained uncut. DNA fragments were separated by electrophoresis on 3% agarose gel and visualized by ethidium bromide staining. The CD40 polymorphism was confirmed by repeated PCR-RFLP. Moreover, the restriction analysis was confirmed by commercial sequencing analysis.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: The prevalence of genotypes in patients and controls was examined for deviation from Hardy–Weinberg equilibrium using exact and log likelihood ratio χ2 tests (http://ihg.gsf.de/cgi-bin/hw/hwa1.pl). The polymorphism was tested for association with SLE incidence using the χ2 test for trend (ptrend). The χ2 test was employed to examine differences in genotypic and allelic distribution between patients and controls, and a p value <0.05 was considered statistically significant. The odds ratio (OR) and 95% confidence intervals (95% CI) were calculated. The association of the CD40 G > T polymorphism with clinical manifestations and the presence of autoantibodies was evaluated by Fischer test. The Bonferroni correction for multiple comparisons was used and both p values, before (p) and after correction (pcorr), were evaluated.

sec.title: Prevalence of CD40 G > T genotypes and alleles in SLE patients and controls
sec.p: Genotype evaluation of the CD40 G > T (rs4810485) polymorphism did not demonstrate significant aberration from the Hardy–Weinberg equilibrium in the patient or control groups.

There was an increased frequency of the TT genotype in controls as compared with patients with SLE; however, these differences were not significant (OR = 0.5626 (95% CI = 0.2535–1.249, p = 0.1521)). We also observed an increased frequency of the TT and GT genotypes in controls compared with patients with SLE, but these differences were also not significant (OR = 0.8535 (95% CI = 0.6319–1.153, p = 0.3015)) (Table 2). There was also no significant change in the frequency of the T allele between the controls and patients (OR = 0.8408 (95% CI = 0.6540–1.081, p = 0.1758)) (Table 2). The p value of the χ2 test for the trend observed for the CD40 G > T (rs4810485) polymorphism was also not statistically significant (ptrend = 0.1654). Table 2

sec.title: Association of CD40 G > T genotypes with clinical symptoms of SLE
sec.p: The most significant p value for differences in the distribution of CD40 TT and GT vs. GG genotype was found in SLE patients with arthritis and neurologic manifestations (OR = 0.2009 (95% CI = 0.07547–0.5348, p = 0.0004, pcorr = 0.0096) and OR = 0.2876 (95% CI = 0.1371–0.6031, p = 0.0005, pcorr = 0.012), respectively) (Table 1). However, there was no association of the CD40 G > T polymorphism with subtypes of neurologic manifestations (Table 1). Moreover, we did not find a significant association between the CD40 G > T polymorphism and the presence of anti-double-stranded (ds)DNA, anti-Smith, anti-snRNP, anti-Ro, anti-Scl-70 or anti-phospholipid antibodies (Abs) (not shown).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In SLE patients, immune cells display abnormal signaling, defective gene expression, reduced T-cell cytotoxicity, and increased humoral response.19,20 CD40L is one of the molecules of which skewed levels in T cells may contribute to the abnormal humoral response occurring in SLE.21 Binding of CD40L to CD40 provides an elementary stimulus for B cell activation, proliferation, immunoglobulin production, isotype switching, and increased expression of other costimulatory molecules.22,23 Thus, CD40 can be one of the candidate molecules involved in the activation of T and B cells and leading to pathology in autoimmune disorders.14 The pathogenic contribution of CD40 has been shown in autoimmune diabetes and thyroiditis, inflammatory bowel disease, psoriasis, multiple sclerosis, RA, and SLE.14 Koshy et al. (1996) demonstrated the role of CD40–CD40L interaction in the pathogenesis of SLE. They showed that SLE T cells cocultured with target B cells induced greater B-cell surface CD80 expression than did activated T cells from healthy individuals.21 Duffau et al. (2010) found that SLE platelets released CD40L, which interacted with CD40 of plasmacytoid dendritic cells, which subsequently secreted interferon-alpha.24 Additionally to these findings, Wang et al. (2002) showed that the action of combined short-term CTLA4Ig and anti-CD40 Abs resulted in prolonged suppression of disease onset in murine SLE models.15 Furthermore, Boumpas et al. (2003) demonstrated that using humanized anti-CD40L antibody in patients with proliferative lupus nephritis decreased the levels of anti-double-stranded (ds) DNA antibodies, increased the C3 concentration, and decreased hematuria.16

The CD40 gene is located in a region (20q11–13) that has been suggested as a locus associated with SLE in European Caucasians, Mexican Americans, and African Americans.25,26 However, in our investigation, we did not find an association between the CD40 G > T (rs4810485) SNP and susceptibility to SLE. Our observations are contradictory to the findings of Vazgiourakis et al. (2011), who demonstrated an association of the CD40 G > T (rs4810485) polymorphism with SLE in Greek and Turkish Mediterranean populations.9

The distinction between the effect of the CD40 G > T (rs4810485) genotype on the risk of SLE in Greek and Turkish populations and our populations may result from genetic heterogeneity, size of the studied groups, and different exposure of the populations to environmental factors.

We also did not find a significant association between the CD40 G > T polymorphism and the presence of anti-dsDNA, anti-Smith, anti-snRNP, anti-Ro, anti-Scl-70, or anti-phospholipid Abs. These negative associations might result from the relatively small size of the studied group of SLE patients and from the fact that only some of those patients tested positive for the analyzed autoantibodies.

However, we found that the CD40 T (rs4810485) gene variant in SLE patients may have negative associations with neurologic manifestations and arthritis. The CD40 T protein variant might reduce the interaction between the CD40–CD40L pair, thereby acting to induce T-cell-mediated humoral responses leading to decreased risk of arthritis in SLE.9,27,28 Vazgiourakis et al. (2011) demonstrated that CD14+ monocytes and CD19+ B cells bearing the GT and TT genotypes exhibited significantly reduced CD40 mRNA and protein levels compared with the GG genotype.9 Moreover, interruption of the CD40–CD40L interaction has been considered a useful therapeutic approach in RA and other autoimmune diseases.27,28 The contribution of the CD40 T variant to the reduction of neurologic manifestations might also result from lower CD40 densities on the surface of either neuronal or immune cells and decreased inflammatory stages.

To date, the CD40 G > T (rs4810485) SNP has also been recognized as a risk factor of RA, psoriasis, Behcet’s disease, and breast cancer in Chinese Han women.8,29–31 Moreover, other CD40 SNPs have been found to contribute to Crohn’s and Graves’ diseases, as well as to manifestations of biopsy-proven giant cell arteritis.32–34 The CD40 gene variants also have an effect on the development of lymphomas, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and some disorders related to the coronary arteries.35–38

Our study did not confirm the CD40 G > T (rs4810485) SNP as a risk factor of SLE in the Polish population, but we found an association of this gene variant with neurologic manifestations and the presence of arthritis in SLE patients. However, to study the detailed role of the CD40 G > T (rs4810485) polymorphism in SLE, this study should be replicated in larger and independent cohorts.
